author: Richard Hartley-Parkinson
title: Man tried to rape deaf and blind woman, 94, at the end of her life during burglary
text:
Gregory Willis has been jailed for trying to rape a 94-year-old woman (Picture: Police handout) A man has been jailed after he tried to rape a deaf and blind 94-year-old woman while burgling her house in the middle of the night.
Jailing him for 14 years, Gregory Willis’s offence was described by a judge as ‘deeply shocking, horrifying and appalling as could possibly be imagined.
He was about to launch his sickening attack at 12.30am when he was caught by a member of his victim’s family.
Newly released stamps show the Queen's castle as well as her face He still had his trousers on but had removed her pyjama bottoms.
Willis got into the house through an open door as a family gathering came to an end and other relatives were chatting in another room.
He was chased away by relatives but returned while the family were on the phone to police at the house in Grantham, Lincolnshire.
His victim died four months after the attack but it was not connected to the attack.
The prosecutor told the court: ‘The victim was in bed, The covers had been pulled back and her pyjama bottoms had been pulled off.
Boy, 10, who died when a Topshop display 'fell on him' has been pictured ‘Had he not been disturbed, as mercifully he was, he was going to rape that 94-year-old lady in that bed.’
Judge John Pini QC said: ‘The victim is 94 years of age. She had not long before this left a nursing home to be cared for in a safe, loving environment for the remaining time of her life.
‘She was registered blind, hard of hearing, had no short term memory, had poor balance and was doubly incontinent. She could not communicate. She was as frail and vulnerable as it is possible to be.’
The victim had been sleeping in the front room of her relative’s home on a hospital trolley after suffering a fall.
Family release shocking photos of bullied teen attacked on his way home from school The relative told the Daily Mail he was ‘shocked and stunned that somebody could intend on doing such a thing.’
Mark Watson, defending him, said Willis could not remember the attack and was under the influence of something. He added that he had apologised for what he had done.
The victim’s son-in-law added: ‘She was a very frail person asleep in bed who had already entered the end of life phase – she didn’t talk very much and although we could take her out in a wheelchair it was becoming increasingly difficult.
‘We don’t know how much of what happened registered with her – we deliberately didn’t raise it with her afterwards and we just have to hope she didn’t suffer in any way.
